ratings.question_text: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
What is your overall rating of the primary instructor?
The primary instructor's sensitivity to students and ability to provide students with adequate feedback was:

narratives.question_text: Indicate the total number of hours per week (outside the classroom) you spent on this course:
comments: 3hr
10-20 depending on if a homework assignment was due or not
roughly 10 hours
15 hrs per week
probably averaged out to 10
10 hours
On weeks with a homework, 10+.
I spent approximately 7 hours per week on this course.

narratives.question_text: Looking back on this course, what is your overall assessment of the course:  What are its strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might it be improved?
comments: I was very disappointed with this class. There was no support and it was taught at such a theoretical level. I found the instructor to not be supportive of our learning.
The contents are hard to understand, it is the most difficult class in Yale I have taken. But the lab notes are pretty helpful.
this is a weird class; the professor hardly explained anything and all I did was copy the codes from the lab and try to get outputs.
lecture slides should be more detailed.
good

The course was disorganized to the point that it was detrimental to student learning. The professor needs to understand what are priorities for learning and what is less important. Also, given that class time is limited, everything should start on time to maximize instruction. The class may be a data class, but there is too much technical detail and not enough emphasis on how to interpret in real-world contexts.

This course was terrible. It was the worst course I have taken thus far at the school of public health. First, basic principles of teaching graduate level courses were not being followed. For example, the lecture slides were very poorly written and poorly organized. Not a single lecture started with a set of objectives outlining what we were supposed to learn that day. We never got all the way through a lecture during the hour and 20 minutes of class. New concepts were introduced on the lecture slides without being defined and put into the larger context of what we were learning. Second, the homework assignments were entirely dependent on the lab handouts. They would have been impossible to do otherwise, as not much teaching went on during the lab sessions either. Third, the homework assignments were incredibly time consuming. This was partly as a result of the poor quality of the lectures. It was also partly because we were expected to complete questions on the homework assignments that were not covered in class or in lab. An inordinate amount of time was spent using Google (at the suggestion of both the instructor and the TA) to figure out how to complete the kinds of analyses we should have been taught in class. Finally, the textbook for this course was not helpful at all. It was very difficult to follow for students who had never seen longitudinal data analysis before. This class was very frustrating and I leave knowing that I will need to take another course on Longitudinal data analysis to make up for what I didn't learn here.
The course is very useful and fundamental. Perhaps more time and credit should be devoted to this course.
i hope the lecture slides could include more examples.
Lecture notes are not clear.

The lectures are not helpful at all, was not clearly organized, nor did it not help much with the homework.Would have liked to have a review of the homework or at least provide an answer key so students can go back and review where they went wrong.
There is a disconnect between what is taught in lecture and lab and what we are asked to do on the homework. It makes the class difficult.

The instructor was a very nice woman. She was approachable and gentle.The course was lousy for several reasons:Very little examples.. Not at all an applied course. So it left me feeling like what is the point of this all. There were so few real Life examples in the material. There was an over reliance on teaching the theory.... Who cares about the theory?If I could have dropped this course I would have.YSPH needs to shape up and correct this problem. The same instructor has been there for years with little change in her technique despite dozens of repeated complaints about the course.

This course is somewhat helpful to understand longitudinal data analysis but could be taught with more clarity. It seemed like simple topics were covered in detail (like what a logit is -- we know that already) but the new material was somewhat glossed over. Perhaps more real world examples would help. Also, the class is somewhat disorganized.
Maybe the lecture notes can be improved to be more well-organized.And I think we can add more things into this course, such as how to deal with the missing data.
The material was difficult to follow, especially for non-biostats students. It would be very helpful to explain some of the basics, if only briefly.
A useful data analysis course.
The professor was a poor teacher, the book was bad, and the TA wasn't helpful. This made it a very difficult and not fun course.

I think there needs to be more of a distinction between the appropriateness of methods for longitudinal data vs. multilevel data. The lecture notes could be improved. The final project was a good way to solidify some of the course material. The homework assignments were generally fine, however there were some questions that we weren't really able to answer based on the course resources.
Awful.

narratives.question_text: Please evaluate the instructor of this course. What are the instructor's strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might his or her teaching be improved?
comments: Instructor: Haiqun Lin  She is obviously smart but unapproachable and did not teach in a way to promote understanding.

Instructor: Haiqun Lin  She is very careful and responsible teacher. I understand the longitudinal models are quite complex and very different from other statistical models. But she still need to work on how to explain the concept and statistical methods clearly and intuitively.
Instructor: Haiqun Lin  good
Instructor: Haiqun Lin  nice

Instructor: Haiqun Lin  The instructor knows the material very thoroughly. However, she needs to learn how to prioritize what to teach--she spends too much time on trivial information in the beginning of class, and then rushes at the end. She also needs to make slides more organized--learning statistics in the slide format is tough, so she should make it more organized.

Instructor: Haiqun Lin  Dr. Lin seems incredibly knowledgeable as a statistician, but she is unable to communicate this knowledge effectively, efficiently, and in an organized and well-though-out manner in the classroom. Dr. Lin lacks basic teaching skills as well as an understanding of her audience. The classroom was a mixture of biostats and non-biostats students and the lecture materials should have been organized with an eye towards that.
Instructor: Haiqun Lin  The instructor has pretty good attitude but somehow it's not so easy to catch what she wants to carry over.
Instructor: Haiqun Lin  I appreciate Dr. Lin's interest in making sure students are getting the main point of the lecture. However, the we never really got through the entire lecture.
Instructor: Haiqun Lin  She is nice and helpful when you are able to meet with her. She is busy and hard to meet with.SAS code needs to explained more in depth

Instructor: Haiqun Lin  The instructor was a very nice woman. She was approachable and gentle.The course was lousy for several reasons:Very little examples.. Not at all an applied course. So it left me feeling like what is the point of this all. There were so few real Life examples in the material. There was an over reliance on teaching the theory.... Who cares about the theory?If I could have dropped this course I would have.YSPH needs to shape up and correct this problem. The same instructor has been there for years with little change in her technique despite dozens of repeated complaints about the course.
Instructor: Haiqun Lin  Dr. Lin is very good and wants us to learn. She sometimes glosses over the more important topics in her lectures. The course felt somewhat disorganized.

Instructor: Haiqun Lin  Dr. Lin is a great prof. I wish we could discuss the material a little more. I would also have liked to have shorter homework assignments (even if there were more) where we were able to cover smaller pieces instead of such large analyses. It made it difficult to get through the homework assignments.
Instructor: Haiqun Lin  Supportive and warm-heart.Sometimes the lectures are not that explicit.
Instructor: Haiqun Lin  Very dry. Just talks through powerpoints. Not an effective way to learn.
Instructor: Haiqun Lin  The lectures were often difficult to follow, but Professor Lin was always willing to take questions and answer them to the best of her ability.

narratives.question_text: If this course included instruction by a teaching assistant (TA), please evaluate the TA here. What are the strengths and weaknesses and how might their teaching be improved? (Specify name of the TA).
comments: Instructor: Gregory Ryslik  He is a nice guy but we didn't go into detail in labs so we could bridge the gaps left by the lecture.
Instructor: Gregory Ryslik  Very funny
Instructor: Gregory Ryslik  Greg is great!
Instructor: Gregory Ryslik  ok

Instructor: Gregory Ryslik  Greg is responsive to student questions and knows the material thoroughly.However, I think that sections would benefit from both conceptual and programming review, not just programming. Lectures are rushed and disorganized, so there needs to be reinforcement of concepts in section. I also think it would be better to hold sections weekly and to have some office hours.

Instructor: Gregory Ryslik  Greg had a tough job as a TA for this class. He essentially had to teach us everything we should have been learning in lecture, and lab was not long enough to allow for this. Greg didn't always exhibit patience or understanding, but I can understand how he would be frustrated having to TA this course.
Instructor: Gregory Ryslik  Pretty good performance.
Instructor: Gregory Ryslik  good!
Instructor: Gregory Ryslik  He's pretty good. Did what he could to help out.

Instructor: Gregory Ryslik  Smart guy but he doesn't know how to explain the material.It is as if he assumes the student have a PhD is biostats, so he doesn't realize how my he needs to simplify things. I guess since the instructor didn't teach the material well in lecture he doesn't have much to work with for the lab sessions.
Instructor: Gregory Ryslik  I think Greg is smart and nice and means well. He sometimes complains about having to help students and it would be great if he didn't do that.
Instructor: Gregory Ryslik  Greg is great at explaining the material. Very knowledgable and easy to approach.
Instructor: Gregory Ryslik  Greg was enthusiastic but not a good teacher. Rather than say, "I don't know", he would make up reasons (e.g., "that's just the way it is").

Instructor: Gregory Ryslik  Greg led good lab sessions that were very helpful for doing the homework. He was very helpful one-on-one as well.Ryan also provided good feedback with grading the homework.
Instructor: Tae Hyun Jung  good
Instructor: Tae Hyun Jung  Greg was knowledgable, and interested in having students learn.
Instructor: Tae Hyun Jung  Helpful and responsible.

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize this course for a fellow student? Would you recommend it to another student? Why or why not?
comments: I would recommend only if quality improved.
Even this course is hard, but it is the only class that teaches you longitudinal data analysis, which is quite useful in future research.So highly recommend.
need more instruction
useful

I would only recommend for people with strong analytical skills and backgrounds--it is not enough to be diligent and generally smart to succeed in this class. There is minimal support and it is easy to get lost. However, the topic is extremely useful.
I would not recommend this course to another student.
Very useful and fundamental.
useful models
I would not recommend this course to a fellow student.
It is just okay. Longitudinal data analysis is very important but I think even after taking the class my understanding about theory and application is not great.

The instructor was a very nice woman. She was approachable and gentle.The course was lousy for several reasons:Very little examples.. Not at all an applied course. So it left me feeling like what is the point of this all. There were so few real Life examples in the material. There was an over reliance on teaching the theory.... Who cares about the theory?If I could have dropped this course I would have.YSPH needs to shape up and correct this problem. The same instructor has been there for years with little change in her technique despite dozens of repeated complaints about the course.
This course is useful but I would not expect to master longitudinal data analysis after this course. I felt that I learned something but that I was slightly confused when this course ended.
This is very useful course, and will help us for both research and work in the future.
Good course. Very difficult material. Some basic, key material is not covered so you will need to google/research a lot.
Great experience.Some theory and some programmings.
I would not recommend this course. The material is essential but the combination of a bad book, bad teacher and bad TA made it hard to learn anything.

This course examined the challenges in analyzing longitudinal data. Several methods for analysis were discussed. I would only recommend this course to a student who has an interest in longitudinal data analysis.
